comments.text:
So the way it seems to be working is that it's purely power limited.

The 9070 xt seems to overclock itself until it reaches the power limit. Increasing the power limit will increase the core clock. Undervolting lets it get more performance for the same wattage, so it'll overclock to reach the power limit.

I honestly like this simple approach, but I wish I could push more than 10%.

comments.text:
I understand the issue with the undervolting Offset stability. Please just go ahead and translate my explanation to english:

Ich verstehe mittlerweile das Undervolting Problem bzgl dem wie viele mV stable sind und wie viel nicht.
Das liegt einfach daran dass die Offset Kurve nicht equivalent skaliert wie die Kurve in der die Karte noch stabil luft.

Da geht es vor allem um die Auslastung und Taktrate der Karte. Meine Karte ist zB in Escape From Tarkov wenig ausgelastet und der Takt ist vielleicht bei 2000 MHz, der Verbrauch bei 180W.. In diesem Gebiet ist meine 9070XT Red Devil nur mit -70mV stabil. Schon bei 75mV ist irgendwann vorbei.

Bei Cyberpunk 2077 hingegen ist die Karte die ganze Zeit stark beansprucht. max Takt und TBP bis ins Powerlimit. 
In dem Bereich ist sie auch mit -120mV stabil - in dem Bereich ist mehr Offset mglich.

Nun habe ich mal -200mV gemacht, was erst stabil lief. Wenn man aber in den Himmel schaut gehen die FPS hoch, die GPU wartet auf die CPU und taktet deshalb runter. -> sie ist bei weniger Verbrauch und Taktrate und genau da ist es dann wieder gecrashed.

Das bedeutet insgesamt, dass man statt nur einem Offset eine angepasste Spannungskurve braucht. 
Die eine Minimalspannung beibehlt und wo dann im oberen Lastbereich immer mehr Luft nach unten mit der Spannung ist als im mittleren und unteren Bereich.
comments.author: @S4N1T03T3R

comments.text: Memory overclock only works until a specific point, for me its ~2760MHz (or 2780MHz slider setting in Adrenalin). Core overclocking is done by undervolting alone without touching Frequency offset slider. Frequency offset slider only works for undervolting without overclocking (you put negative frequency offset along with voltage offset so you have less voltage and less frequency). However so far I am unable to find any stable memory overclock setting with either default or fast timing. With only core overclocked I am able to run stable at -80mV, frequency at 0 and power target +10.

comments.text: My guess is AMD aggressively priced these chips to compete with the 5070 ti. IF you can get one at MSRP then your mileage may vary in OC depending on which chip you get. Obviously the AIB's are aggressively binning these chips and charging more for higher clocked chips adding to their margins. NVidia on the other hand has superior support for FG built into game engines which boosts performance as long as you don't use the insane 4x multiplier which is obviously broken. 2x works perfect, 3x is starting to exhibit artifacts and 4x is a blurry mess. I think this will improve with additional training to the transformer model and will only get better with future games. FSR3 FG has been extremely sparse in support in engine and AFMF is a brute force method akin to frame interpolation on TV's which produces motion artifacts and obviously their on chip ML is not as strong as NVidia.

comments.author: @ggoddkkiller1342

comments.text:
There isn't much power reduction from vRAM. The reason your GPU can beat the desktop one is because it has 7% more cuda cores. It wouldn't be faster otherwise. 
For example, the 16GB 4060 ti version only consumes like 10% more power than the 8GB version. vRAM isn't as power-hungry as many people think. This is also why the cooling system isn't put directly on the memory chips and the heat is transferred via thermal pads, which is enough for them, as the GPU chip produces way more heat than vRAM does.
comments.author: @TabalugaDragon

comments.text: @TabalugaDragon It can reach 2100 Mhz with undervolting! So it doesn't come close to desktop performance with less power, literally beats it. 10% is still massive difference, not something you can ignore. For example with 170 TDP it makes 17 watts, making it way closer to my 130 watts power consumption. If they limited power very close memory consumption might affect performance. Laptop GPUs are severely power limited and i can't push VRAM much neither, i can only increase performance by undervolting.
comments.author: @ggoddkkiller1342

comments.text:
@ 10% is insignificant compared how much performance is lost if there isn't enough RAM for a game. 
10% of power for the GPU is roughly 5% difference in raw performance(since the higher the clockspeeds and power are, the less efficient a GPU becomes), whereas if there isn't enough vram, performance difference can be 3, even 5 times or 200-400%. 
When my laptop 3070 ti runs out of vram I get 20, sometimes 10fps compared to 90-100 I get when I have enough vram. 
And games only get more and more demanding as time goes by.

I don't know if AMD allows it, but through Afterburner, Nvidia owners can specify specific clock-rates at specific voltages through the little bar button near the clock rate slider, you can adjust the voltage-frequency. If AMD has a similar type of hardcore manual adjustments, you're probably better off just using something like that to push the card. It's clear that 3.4Ghz might be attainable stably and anything higher than 3.1 Ghz is already more of an overclock than base.

If anything, the fact it's so easy to push 3.2Ghz from a simple mV adjustment and power plan utilization is nice and simple. -100, +10%, enjoy a near 5080 in some titles. Though obviously, the real fun comes in trying to attain 3.2Ghz whilst using less power than a full brunt 360 Watts.

comments.text: The card is already set up to sit on the floor of the AVFS curve, and the main limiter in almost every 3D workload is now the power limit - so increasing the clock offset does nothing because it is power limited, but decreasing the voltage offset allows the card to think it needs less voltage for a given frequency, and therefore can boost higher until it hits the power limit again. The clock offset on AMD cards is just a suggestion, even on 6x00/7x00 series, there is a "min frequency" and "max frequency" slider, where in most cases the max frequency raises the boost behavior in games, but if the power limit is hit and the min frequency is set very high, the GPU will try to undervolt when against power limit to maintain the min frequency even if voltage offset was not used (often with instability). In a way, similar to the curve shaper option in Ryzen CPU, but applied in a different context. It looks like the 9070 series remove the min frequency slider, and only the max frequency slider exists, with AMD setting it by default well above the clock speeds the card will hit in gaming / 3D due to power constraints. Someone mentioned nearing 4 GHz in light compute workloads on a 9070 XT, so maybe the potential is there for >3.5 GHz with a very high power limit (450w, etc.)

@der8auer For AMD GPUs, Adrenalin software is much better suited for OC/UV than MSI After Burner or tools like GPU Tweak. Simply because these tools cause more and more compatibility problems with the Adrenalin software or the AMD GPU driver, unfortunately. Which is also known.

It would therefore have made much more sense to use the Adrenalin software for the test.
So there is nothing wrong with AMD here, the problem is the tool you are using.

The MSI After Burner doesn't offer any AMD compatibility settings for nothing, but unfortunately these are useless.

Overclocking is no longer the way to go in 2025 (actually it has been for a long time) anyway. Undervolting is always the most sensible way for 24/7.

Thats probably working as intended, or at least how it was designed because I had a similar experience tweaking the settings on my much older RDNA cardthe RX 5700 XT.  I found that giving it a little bump to the VRAM and undervolting the GPU got me more performance.  That card was a reference PCB so it had a shitty loud blower, so it was awful at any speed, but it worked great for me at the time and made me a ton of money mining on it in 2020-2021 after I upgraded to an RTX 3070 that performed as well at mining, but cost me more money to run because it just used more power.

RDNA is just such a weird architecture thats insanely power efficient and Im convinced they ship the cards with more voltage than is optimal because the bigger number looks better on the box.  Personally I care about more performance first and volume second, so it sounds like the sort of card Id probably like to own.

It might be a fun card to run on LN2, because of how much more performance it gets out of improved cooling.

I bought 9070XT and I am very disapointed by their drivers, it's the same half working mess as 6+ years ago when I had AMD card for the last time. Even totally basic settings like image scaling or integer scaling don't work and I was very used to using integer scaling for old games when I had nvidia. Are people really ok with these AMD drivers or they just don't care? Their anti-lag also does nothing, I was used to nvidia reflex that made games playable even with only 40 FPS by lowering lag, but with AMD, I need like 80+ FPS to stop feeling delay. Performance is very good, I can't complain about performance, but those drivers....
I know that the vast majority of today people probably don't care about some integer scaler, but when it is in settings, it should work! And it's good for older games that have too small GUI in 4K, so you can just set 1080p and it looks like native becuase 1920x2=3840, so you can just multiplay it by 2 for your 4K screen, this works perfectly with nvidia cards.
My XFX 9070XT has really loud coils, but it happens mostly with very high FPS or in games like Stalker 2, it's kind of annoying, I hope I will get used to it, in the past, I had Corsair PSU that also had these loud coils and I threw it into garbage for exactly this reason.

If there was no shortage of nvidia stocks, I would probably not even think about AMD card, becuase everytime when I buy AMD card, it will end like "AMD never again" but after years, I am always like "ok, let's test AMD after few years, maybe they finally fixed their drivers...."  no, they didn't. Intel also plans their version of nvidia reflex feature, so let's hope it's gonna be available for all GPUs, I would love intel for that. It's sad that Intel is not able to bring us proper higher end GPUs, I already consider their drivers better than AMD.

comments.text: Basically the way to memory overclock these Radeon cards is to just increase the clock until you start noticing a decrease in performance and then dial it back again. They'll let you increase the clock beyond the point where they're actually stable and then they'll try to force stability at the cost of performance instead of just crashing outright. It's also important to undervolt them if you want any significant performance boost as it's an offset across the entire frequency curve.

comments.text: The reason why undervolting increases the performance is because it's an offset across the entire frequency curve. Basically by lowering the voltage you are increasing the max clock you can reach up until you either hit what you've set your max frequency to or you run into your power limit (or you crash). By using a more robust model you have a larger power limit and more thermal headroom to work with (as well as presumably a better bin than cheaper models).

comments.text: Man, oc isnt broken, you just dont understand how it works on these cards. The voltage and frequency sliders arent a fixed point, youre moving the entire v/f curve when you adjust them. The card will boost to different clocks based on that curve youre shifting. Think of it like PBO and curve optimizer in the ryzen cpus. Memory, it starts to lose performance due to error correction, so you need to find a frequency point where you start to see performance regression and that will be your max memory oc. And if you use adrenaline, you can enable fast timings, which sets a more aggressive memory timing strap.
comments.author: @Rmmmmmmmmmmk

comments.text:
Also Der8auer seems to have a bit of a misunderstanding about the memory, because it's error correcting so that when you raise the clock too far it doesn't just crash, but instead the increasing error correction begins to hinder performance. It's not a bug, it's the error correction doing what it's supposed to do.

Also the overclocking isn't "broken", and the voltage slider does not affect the absolute voltage, it affects the voltage curve. And the clocks behave in relation to that voltage curve. Simply put, you "overclock" the gpu by adjusting the voltage curve, not adjusting the clocks itself.

comments.text:
Based on my experience from 6750XT and 7800XT i can tell these things.

1. Voltage slider shifts whole curve (and finally Adrenalin tells you that in helper text). It also is not mapped as 1 to 1, so 50 mV shift of curve will shift voltage at, say, 2000 MHz by around 6 mV, while on fixed high clock, voltage can be reduced by 50 mV and possibly even more.

But, there is safe range which does not affect clocks up to certain point 

For 7800XT it didn't affect voltage up to around 1800 MHz. 

2. While on 6750XT VRAM OC is straightforward, on 7800XT it is tricky. It doesn't error. It doesn't artifact. It either loses performance, or causes random and sudden reboots of PC (at moment of such reboot it usually also logs singular WHEA... 19(?) I believe... error). And it can happen even weeks after you find your seemingly stable value.

I assume RDNA4 is in similar position, due to error correction in work.
comments.author: @DimkaTsv

comments.text: I have been overclocking amd gpus since the thousand island architecture, you are spot on with rdna especially with the 6900xt and amds other higher tier. Gpus the closer your base core speed is to the boost  the less fluctuations you have with the voltage. I really wish the more power tool was still usable since when you take of certain limiters and stuff you can  do some crazy things on the 6800xt and upwards..
comments.author: @joshuagreer8046

comments.text:
@joshuagreer8046 Thanks. These conclusions came from my own experience with 6750XT and 7800XT OC and UV.

Sadly either my 7800XT, or RDNA3 is very hard to properly undervolt. Yes, you can run consistent loads at max frequency and something like 1050 mV curve (from default 1150). But as soon as you try to put into variable spiky load (game with spiky load and limited FPS), it all falls apart. And it seems like there are more people with similar experience of undervolting being really good for many loads, but almost instantly failing in others.

I spent two weeks testing undervolts for my 7800XT. And in the end, result was 1135 mV is most that i could do (aka just -15 mV). Any less and it would become unstable. Even though to crash GPU at 1125 mV it took almost 48 hours of automated test scene running. And another week or two of real usage to get crash on 1130 mV. This borderline stability is not enough for me. 

But oh well, at least my GPU is pretty much stable. I did have 2 similar VRAM caused reboots in a year (it is also OC'ed, of course), but after second one i dropped another 10 mHz from VRAM clock, so it should be fine now.
comments.author: @DimkaTsv

comments.text: @DimkaTsv any time mate I am always keen to tinker and learn from others experience, inherently amds rdna architecture from the factory is not voltage limited but thermally the sky is the limit I have put a water block on all those aforementioned cards and it has shown exactly that the silicon quality is what matters as well aib variants that higher quality will have a higher binned card etc same.With the memory even though rdna2 and up does not gain much from memory oc memory quality and having memory that stays cool under load  helps with keeping your core much more  stable  therefore your clock speeds will maintain for much longer that and  just remember amds memory  is ecc so you can raise your memory.  the clocks higher but your entire clock speed curve will be affected :)
comments.author: @joshuagreer8046

comments.text: @DimkaTsv hi. can u advice on what games or software you used for stability test is best?  i have 7800xt too and trying UV for lower temps without loss of performance. thx.
comments.author: @sergeygorbov3955

comments.text:
@sergeygorbov3955 For me, i use mostly Warframe. This game is something else in terms of sensitivity. 
For RDNA3 i lock 1080p and 144 FPS on max settings. For manual tesing, just play. For automatic... You can set up captura with enemies with enabled AI. 

Some people report Fortnite is pretty decent for tests. Some people report Monster Hunter: Wild is stability nightmare... So there is no singular solution out here. 

In general, it should be relatively low load by default, aka in between spikes resulting at around 120-150W. But it should vary much, and produce spikes up to 220+W of reported power. You probably should hear these spikes in coil whine.

These load spikes are main stress factor for voltage stability on RDNA3. Sadly i could not even underclock my card enough to make it stable below 1135 mV.

comments.text:
Going to try doing this on my ASRock Taichi 9070 XT when I get it.

Edit: Finally dialed in a 100% stable overclock of my Taichi.

My overclock numbers are: Power Limit +5, Voltage Offset -40mV and VRAM max frequency 2,758MHz with Fast Timings. 

Ran a full 99 run benchmark with Metro Exodus Enhanceds benchmark at 4K Extreme. Only benchmark I had on hand that would crash at the slightest hint of instability.

I turned off the zero RPM as its temperature threshold is too high. Fan speeds set to 20, 30, 40, 45, 50 to keep the noise down. Temperature thresholds set to 30, 40, 45, 50, 55 as about 55C is where the GPU maxes out on edge temp.

Temperatures max out at 56C GPU, 92C Hot Spot and 92C VRAM. Hot Spot and VRAM actually maxed out at 96C when I began tuning, but I guess the thermal paste needed breaking in.

Power Limit increase of +10 does boost performance slightly and allows for -5mV more Voltage Offset, but produces an additional 5C on the Hot Spot and VRAM that is too much for my quiet fan curve with the VRAM becoming unstable even at stock frequency.

Max Frequency Offset increases of up to +20MHz are possible, but causes unstable average frame rates at every +5MHz increase: graphics driver crash at 25MHz. GPUs clock maxes out to 3405MHz by default with the performance BIOS anyway.

Fast Timings on the VRAM only dropped my max frequency from 2764MHz to 2,758MHz.

Superposition 1080p Extreme average went from 106.46 to 113.5. Heaven 1440p Ultra average went from 139.1 to 149.9.

Enjoying Cyberpunk 2077 at an average 114FPS from 106FPS at the same settings. Can only match the stock 5080 running at the same settings as in the video, though my tuning is 100% stable for real world gaming and not some benchmark for around a minute and a half.

Glad to be done with tuning until I need to replace the thermal paste with probably a thermal pad made out of a phase change material.

I don't get why the go to is to try and Overclock the 9070xt that draws 304w when the non-xt card is only 10-15% slower while drawing 220w.

From the paper specs it looks to me like the xt is being pushed quite hard out of the box as 15% more shaders and 80w higher power limit would to my mind produce a bigger uplift in performance than we see. Also its a bit of a so what overclock its not catching up to any card in a meaningfully usefull way to consumers, buy a card at the same price as the 5070ti (or its msrp at least) and still be behind in RT/image quality while drawing more power isn't imo a compelling thing to do. I like OC so for fun sure but not particularly worthwhile on this card I feel.

What does seem worthwhile would be to see how the 9070 overclocks because 5-10% extra frame rate via overclocking would make it close the gap down with the xt given the 9070 has better availabilty at not insane price inflation. Surely buying the card thats say 12% slower then halving that gap on a card thats 10-30% cheaper would be great for people looking for an upgrade no?

@beowulf885 8 pins don't get hot at their rated 150 wattage, 200 wattage maybe they get warm. 250 watts and that's a hot wire like the 12v connectors.

Also the PCI-E port provides a base of 75 watts into the sum.

So 75w + (150w * # of 8pins).
That's the max wattage the GPU can utilize.

As a result having at least a 850 watt PSU is required as minimum if you wish to constantly use 350-450 watts of power, as your CPU and everything else draws from the others.

I suspect its very similar to on my 7900xt in how the clocks work which took a little getting used to from older cards.

Your right that you can do whatever you like with the Core Clock slider and it will do essentially nothing by itself, what your doing is setting maximums that the card will throtle itself at once it hits one of those limits. Vram works like normal but if you go too high it will either crash or just give performance regression I think thats error correction at work.


As for the core OC as you reduce the voltage the clock should increase and also give you more head room to increase the power limit to push the clocks even higher but its all a balancing act of temp, voltage and watts. what I do is set a 3000mhz target from the 2730mhz default then reduce the voltage and add power limit incrementally, I don't hit that 3000mhz target but instead of sitting around 2645 sustained it will go to ~2800 or even a little higher in some workloads and will peak for short periods at 29xx.

I would assume the new cards will be very similar to that behavior and it can be hard to see whats working or isn't at first (I wasn't sure anyway) however it took my Timespy graphics score from 26000 something (just below 27K iirc) up to 30300 and produces results in actual games although less impressive than catching the xtx(29/30K)/being 20% behind a 4090 (34/36K).

I think the 9070 might be the better card this gen because if it OCs and isn't hobbled in some way by AMD its got a huge power budget before it catches up to the 9070xt in terms of draw but not that far to go untill it ties the performance so I wish you luck and hope this is helpfull. oh and after thought you might get clocks that show higher and performace goes backwards so do keep an eye out for that

comments.text:
Nothing is wrong with the core overclocking, people just get confused by Radeon OC because it's different from Nvidia.

It works much like PBO. Max clock offset is akin to PBO max offset (max achievable clock if not limited by other factors like power).

Voltage offset is actually voltage curve offset. If you imagine a curve like in Afterburner for Nvidia, reducing voltage on the slider is the same as moving the entire curve left (which is mathematically the same as moving it upward).

For this reason, "undervolting" is literally the same thing as overclocking, until you run into the max clock speed you set. 

It all makes a little more sense if you use the Adrenalin software for tuning, but people still get confused constantly and there is tons of misinformation out there on things like "why RX cards run faster on lower voltage" (they don't).
comments.author: @temporaltomato3021

comments.text: So this card is not running faster by lowering the voltage?
comments.author: @austinr09

comments.text: @austinr09 It's more complex than that but voltages being lowered will never help you achieve higher performance unless you are thermal or Power limited. Gpus have a voltage and core clock curve. So they automatically boost to use the thermal and power headroom that is available to them (Exactly like how ryzen works). This means if you increase that negative voltage offset you shift the entire curve not just the gaming clock. So if at stock you run at 1.2v 3ghz 300w and you then apply a -100 offset you then still use roughly 1.2v go up to like 3.2ghz at 300w. If you then take that same profile and power limit it to like 250w it would run at like 1.1v 3 ghz 250w. So it is not running faster by lowering the voltage at the top(Like the top part where you boost in a demanding game) it is running faster by lowering the entire curve and then your clocks AT THE SAME VOLTAGE are higher. This might seem pedantic but there is a real distinction. You could also think about it as shifting all the voltage tables points up by a certain number of mhz. The outcome would be the same but AMD doesn't display it like that. Basically AMD makes it so any profile is an Undervolt or an overclock. All you have to do to choose which one you want is move the power slider to change how much watts you want it to use.

comments.text: Nothing happens when changing max clock because you're adjusting the boost clock/voltage curve while you are limited by tpb, so it will eventually shift you out of that part of the PPT curve and your clocks will drop slightly. Recent drivers have been weird with overclocking, if we still had full curve control you could likely get overclocks at specific voltage and expected tbp levels. Same happens on the 7900XTX. It's also why you get weird clock fluctuation when adjusting voltage because the PPT still goes past your set voltage and clock point.

comments.text: VRAM overclock is hitting error correction. You push VRAM too high, it starts to generate errors, but the card actually detects those and retries. So performance goes down as you push VRAM too high. The trick is to find the highest VRAM clock that does NOT degrade performance. This is the modern way and a good thing - you won't seen random rendering corruption when you push VRAM too high, instead you see perf going down. This is how 3090 and 5090 work, but unlike how 4090 works (which was super annoying as it allows dishonest overclockers to push VRAM to the moon, get a big number out of a benchmark but the test may or may not have rendered everything correctly. Usually if VRAM was pushed real high there, the answer was "the test did not render correctly".

comments.text:
The reason you are seeing a regression when increasing memory clocks is because of EDR (Error Detection and Replay). If the GPU detects an error, it will resend the data. In your overclock, too many errors are happening which slows everything down instead of crashing.
If the clockspeed increases with lower voltage (and lower temperature) then there is potential it will clock even higher if watercooled or with LN2.

comments.text:
YES, came here to say this myself. The Adrenalin software explains that the voltage offset is "across all frequencies", ie the curve.

Content creators everywhere have been confused on tuning these cards for generations of Radeon, and have confused others themselves.

"Clock offset" works exactly the same as PBO max offset - it doesn't increase frequency at same voltage, it increases max achievable frequency when all other boost criteria are in place (not power/voltage/thermal limited).

Voltage offset slider only goes down and not up because it's moving the invisible voltage/frequency curve to the left to overclock the card. Moving the v/f curve left is the same as moving it upward, as we're used to seeing on Nvidia. It is the same thing mathematically.

Edit: To put it another way, moving the voltage slider down on Radeon is the same thing as setting a +(x)MHz offset on GeForce (up to the max clock offset you set).

comments.text:
@Syphirioth It is mostly applicable for all modern GPU's as they run at high clocks. 

Just plain overclocking 3000-3200 will give you at most 2-3% performance, as clocks are not 1:1 to performance. 

Power limit gain also depends on where on efficiency curve GPU is placed. There may be chance that Nvidia GPU's will scale slighly better with power.

But! Undervolting scaling improves efficiency, and allows reaching higher clocks, while  (or due to) reducing power consumption. 

So by doing undervolt you actually throwing three stones at once (even though only 2 targets can be hit). Increasing efficiency. Increasing performance. Reducing power consumption

comments.text:
@platinumsun4632 MorePowerTool... Up until RDNA3 it was tool for extending functionality to overclock AMD GPU's via editing SPPT table in Windows registry. 

It could toggle functionality flags, edit frequencies (including FCLK) and power ranges to be able to set them outside of range given within VBIOS. 

As special functionality it could even adjust V/F curve by editing values that it gives to formula, and frequency/voltage of VRAM power steps. 

RDNA2 locked part of capabilities, afaik, but most still worked. RDNA3 locked basically everything.

Cannot say that it is bad, ngl. You could really mess up GPU by tinkering without knowing what you were doing.

@ If you not use MPT You might get better performance with some strange settings not realy making sense.

How I see it? Everything is a lever under the wings of the true power limit. Can A go that high then B might be reduced. Or C is reduced. Or D is reduced. or it needs B it will reduce A a bit etc. All within the total power consumption.

comments.text: @gstormcz It's only link-ECC, not end-to-end.  The extra bits aren't stored in the RAM, just generated and sent over the bus. So it doesn't cost more, and it doesn't protect against decay or flaky rows. Just lets them run the memory clock higher, with a well-defined error margin, instead of "too low to test", which is what you have to shoot for if you don't have any ECC. Link ECC is a standard feature of GDDR (and now DDR5).
